query: What is the university stance on Academic Freedom?

The common good relies on the free search for truth and its free exposition.  For over ninety years, the AAUP has been involved in developing standards to protect academic freedom and advocating for their acceptance within the higher education community. The AAUP is recognized as an authoritative voice in the academic profession regarding academic freedom. Its statements, reports, and policies on academic freedom, along with other key issues, are published in the AAUP's Policy Documents and Reports, also known as the "Redbook." This reflects the university's commitment to upholding and promoting the principles of academic freedom as fundamental to its mission and operations.

answer: The ethical standards faculty should observe, as outlined in Section 355.6 of the Faculty Administration Manual, include the following key responsibilities and behaviors:  1. **Commitment to Knowledge**: Professors must have a deep conviction of the worth and dignity of advancing knowledge. query: To what extent can faculty organize and bargain?
answer: Faculty members within the California State University (CSU) system, including those at California State University and Colleges (CSUC), have the opportunity to organize and engage in collective bargaining, as provided by the California Higher Education Employer-Employee Relations Act (HEERA). This act, enacted into law on September 13, 1978, by Governor Edmund G. Brown, Jr., is codified in the Education Code Section 3560, et seq.  HEERA grants faculty members the right to determine if they wish to be represented by an exclusive agent in negotiations concerning "wages, hours of employment, and other terms and conditions of employment" (HEERA, Section 3561, r.). Importantly, the legislation also aims to preserve traditional shared governance mechanisms, including consultation and the principle of peer review in faculty personnel decisions. The Academic Senate focuses on educational and professional matters, ensuring they do not become subjects of bargaining. It continues to serve as the official voice of faculties in systemwide academic and professional matters, maintaining responsibilities related to academic policies, standards, and governance, separate from collective bargaining issues.  In summary, faculty within the CSU system can organize and bargain collectively on employment-related matters, while the Academic Senate plays a key role in academic governance and policymaking, distinct from the bargaining process.

Mini-grants can be used for support such as reassigned time, student assistants, clerical help, and supplies and services directly related to the project.   2. Summer Research Fellowships provide financial support for faculty to start, continue, or complete a substantial project. Faculty can apply for either a stipend or research expenses, including supplies, travel, or student support.   3. Faculty Research Awards provide reassigned time to develop or complete a substantial creative scholarship or research project. The department/school in which the faculty member resides will receive funding for two-course reassigned time at the internal rate.   To be eligible for these grants, you must be a tenure-track or tenured faculty member. Faculty in the Faculty Early Retirement Program are ineligible. Applications are made using a standardized format available from the Office of Academic Research, with submissions deadlined as indicated in the 'call for proposals'.  Proposals must include: - a list of all grants received in the past three years - a clear demonstration of the significance of the project for both the faculty member's professional development and the body of knowledge in their discipline  - a clear and concise description of the project, its objectives, methods, and feasibility, using non-specialist language  - a budget with itemized expenditures and justifications, if applicable  Applications are evaluated by College Professional Awards Committees according to specified criteria. Recommendations are forwarded to the Dean or University Librarian, and then to the Office of Academic Research, who forward ranked recommendations to the Vice President for Academic Affairs/Provost for a final decision.   Award recipients are required to submit a report on the use of the award and the completed project to the Office of Academic Research by a specified deadline.

query: Tell me the steps to give a faculty member the OSRCA Award.
answer: The steps to give a faculty member the Outstanding Scholarship, Research, Creative Activities Award (OSRCA) are as follows:  1. The Office of Undergraduate Studies announces the procedures and deadline for nominations at the beginning of the fall semester. 2. Any faculty member or academic administrator may nominate an eligible faculty member by submitting a nomination form and a brief statement explaining why the faculty member merits the award. 3. The University Awards Committee reviews and evaluates the nominations according to the established criteria. 4. The Committee recommends the names of the award recipients to the President. 5. The President decides on the awardees and informs the Committee of their decision. 6. The awardees are recognized at the annual Faculty Recognition Luncheon and during graduation ceremonies in their college. Their names are also listed on a dedicated University website page along with past recipients.

query: What is the university stance on Academic Freedom?
answer: Academic freedom is a fundamental and indispensable quality of institutions of higher education. According to the AAUP's core policy statement, academic freedom allows institutions of higher education to be conducted for the common good rather than for individual benefits. It depends upon the free search for truth and its free exposition.   As stated in the FAM, professors are expected to seek and state the truth as they see it and devote their energies to improving their scholarly competence. They should also encourage the free pursuit of learning in their students and hold scholarly standards for them. Furthermore, professors have obligations as colleagues to respect the free inquiry of their associates and show due respect for the opinions of others. As members of the academic community, they should participate in faculty responsibilities for the governance of their institution. Although professors follow the stated regulations of the institution, they reserve the right to criticize and seek changes if regulations contravene academic freedom.  Importantly, academic freedom also extends to professors' accounts of their professional activities, which must be honest like their professional work. Faculty members are responsible for upholding these academic freedom standards, and any suspected violations should be reported to the Associate Provost for Faculty Affairs and Development for investigation and appropriate action.

query: What are the ethical standards faculty should observe?
answer: According to the FAM, faculty members are expected to adhere to ethical standards that revolve around the following concepts:  - Academic Freedom: Faculty should uphold the principle of academic freedom, which allows for the free search for truth and its exposition, being guided by a deep conviction about the significance of knowledge advancement.   - Responsibility to Students: Professors should demonstrate respect for students, fostering honest academic conduct and ensuring that evaluations reflect each student's true merit. They must maintain the confidential nature of the professor-student relationship and avoid exploitation, harassment, or discriminatory treatment.  - Respect for Colleagues: Faculty members should respect their colleagues, their inquiries, and their opinions during the exchange of ideas and criticism. They should acknowledge the academic debts and avoid discriminating against or harassing colleagues.   - Professional Activities: In accounts of their professional activities, faculty members are expected to maintain honesty, integrity, and transparency. This applies to FARs, AARs, grant applications, and other related reports.   - Academic Integrity: Faculty should practice intellectual honesty in their work and avoid compromising their academic freedom or inquiry for subsidiary interests.   - Community Responsibilities: Faculty have obligations as members of the community, which they should fulfill while considering their primary responsibilities to their subject, students, profession, and institution. When expressing personal views, they should clarify that they are not representing the institution.   - Ethical Research: Faculty are expected to adhere to the Policy on Upholding Research Integrity and Responding to Allegations of Research Misconduct when conducting research.   Additionally, faculty should report any suspected violations of ethical standards to the appropriate authorities, such as the Associate Provost for Faculty Affairs and Development.

query: How would a faculty member conduct a faculty exchange?
answer: A faculty exchange may be arranged within the CSU system or with another public or private institution of higher learning. Faculty exchanges are typically for faculty who have been at the institution for an extended period and would benefit from the renewal offered by an exchange agreement.  The responsibility lies with the faculty member to initiate the exchange and find a suitable exchanging faculty member. The faculty member should then request approval from their Department Chairman and College Dean in a written memo. The exchanging faculty member must be acceptable to the gaining department.   The exchange should be arranged early in the academic year to allow for curricular and scheduling changes to be made and normally lasts for one academic year. An exchange agreement will be signed by both faculty members involved, along with appropriate administrative officers of the institutions.

query: To what extent can faculty organize and bargain?
answer: According to the Faculty Administration Manual (FAM), faculty members of the CSUC have the opportunity to form an exclusive representation body for negotiating "wages, hours of employment, and other terms and conditions of employment". This is in accordance with The California Higher Education Employer-Employee Relations Act (HEERA), which was signed into law in 1978.   The Academic Senate of the CSUC is the official voice of the faculty in systemwide academic and professional matters. It serves as a shared governance body and is responsible for formulating and adopting recommendations relating to university policies, curricular matters, and criteria for faculty appointments, among other things. The Senate also has the power to initiate faculty referenda and elections for various faculty representative bodies.   Faculty senates at the campus level have a similar role in governing academic and professional matters within their institutions. They are the primary consultative bodies for campus presidents on these issues. Additionally, faculty members have certain ethical responsibilities, which include intellectual honesty, respect for students, and adherence to academic freedom principles.   In summary, faculty can organize and collectively bargain through their elected representatives, while also being bound by the ethical standards outlined in the FAM.

query: How can the Senate conduct a referendum?
answer: The Senate can conduct a referendum in the following way: 1. The Faculty Senate, by a majority vote, can initiate a referendum on proposed amendments to the Constitution. 2. Alternatively, a referendum can be initiated by a petition signed by 20% of the Faculty. 3. Ratification of the proposed amendments requires a two-thirds affirmative vote of all valid ballots cast. The ratification election must be conducted by the Elections Committee, with all members of the faculty, except those on full-time leave of absence without pay, eligible to vote. 4. A copy of the proposed amendments must be sent to every faculty member at least one week before ballots are distributed, and a minimum of ten working days must be given from the day ballots are distributed to the deadline for receiving them in the Senate Office.

query: What is in the faculty senate constitution?
answer: The Faculty Senate Constitution contains information on the roles and responsibilities of the Faculty Senate and its members, as well as the procedures for elections, committee formations, and the approval of proposals.   Some key points include:  - Membership and Voting Rights: Outlines who is eligible to be a member of the faculty and their voting rights. This includes provisions for tenure-line faculty, lecturers, and library staff. Faculty on paid leave and those participating in the Faculty Early Retirement Program (FERP) retain voting rights.  - Powers of the Faculty: The Faculty has the power to recommend and revise policies related to the University's operations, subject to state laws, CSU Trustees regulations, and the Collective Bargaining Agreement. This power is primarily exercised through the Faculty Senate.   - Faculty Senate Structure and Officers: Defines the Faculty Senate's structure, including membership, officers, and their terms of service. The Senate officers include the Chair, Vice Chair, and Executive Secretary, who are elected by Senate members.  - General Faculty Meetings: States that the University President or their designee shall call at least one faculty meeting during the academic year, with special meetings called as needed. Faculty can also request meetings through a petition.  - The Faculty Senate's Relationship with Committees: Details the relationship between the Faculty Senate and various committees, including standing committees like Curriculum, Educational Policy and Resources, and Faculty Affairs. It outlines the election processes and terms of service for committee members.  - Elections and Voting Procedures: Establishes guidelines for nominations, elections, and voting procedures for various faculty representatives, including senators, committee members, and representatives to the Statewide Academic Senate. It ensures anonymous voting processes.  - Resignations and Recalls: Faculty representatives who cannot fulfill their responsibilities may be asked to resign, and a recall election can be initiated if they do not. The process involves the Elections Committee investigating and potentially initiating a recall ballot.  - Academic Freedom: Reaffirms the importance of academic freedom and faculty's responsibility to uphold it.  - Establishment of Departments and Schools: Sets criteria and guidelines for proposing and establishing new academic departments or schools within the University. It also outlines the process for changing a department's or school's name.  - Exceptional Service to Students Award: Outlines the purpose, eligibility criteria, and application process for the Exceptional Service to Students Award, which supports faculty in student mentoring, advising, and other exceptional service activities.  - Research, Scholarship, and Creative Activity Awards: Describes the purpose and categories of these awards, which support faculty research and professional development. It outlines the application process, evaluation criteria, and reporting requirements.   - University-Level Awards: Establishes the criteria and process for nominating and selecting recipients of University-level awards for outstanding professors, lecturers, scholarship, research, creative activities, and service.   - Faculty Exchange Program: Faculty may initiate exchanges with other CSU campuses or institutions. The policy outlines the eligibility requirements, approval processes, and administrative procedures for faculty exchanges.   - Ancillary Units: Provides guidelines for establishing, organizing, and reviewing Ancillary Units (e.g., centers, institutes) that support the University's academic missions. It covers leadership structure, reporting requirements, and review procedures.   The Constitution also includes provisions for amending its provisions, forming committees, and adopting a Faculty Senate Constitution. It emphasizes the preservation of shared governance mechanisms and academic freedom in the context of collective bargaining.

query: What are the responsibilities of school heads?
answer: The responsibilities of school heads, also referred to as "directors" in the Faculty Administration Manual (FAM), include:  1. Supporting the mission of the University by offering approved academic courses and programs in their respective disciplines and promoting academic inquiry and critical thinking.  2. Ensuring the rights and responsibilities of Academic Freedom for their faculty, as outlined in FAM 355.6.  3. Providing a plan for a sufficient number of tenure-line faculty to deliver the curriculum and engage in shared governance activities. School heads are also responsible for soliciting and incorporating feedback from their faculty.  4. Initiating and leading the process of establishing a new academic department or school, including collaborating with stakeholders, and submitting proposals to the appropriate college dean(s) for approval, following the guidelines and timelines outlined in FAM Section 112.35.  5. School heads are expected to play a role in the shared governance mechanisms of the University. They consult with the campus president on academic matters and contribute to the development of policies.  6. School heads should foster an environment of collegiality and collective bargaining, as outlined in FAM Section 402.0. This includes consulting with the Academic Senate on matters related to the appointment, promotion, and tenure of academic employees, while preserving the principle of peer review.  7. They are also responsible for ensuring compliance with the curricular processes and guidelines when proposing new degree programs within their school.  8. School heads facilitate the solicitation of external funding for their school, in alignment with the FAM's guidelines.  9. School heads may also propose changes to the name of their department or school, initiated by a majority vote of the faculty within the unit, and following the process outlined in FAM Section 112.35.  Overall, the responsibilities of school heads involve academic leadership, shared governance, and adherence to University policies and procedures.

query: An ancillary unit has disbanded. What are the administrative steps to take?
answer: According to the FAM, an ancillary unit that is disbanded will have its residual funds and property custody transferred to the academic unit or administrative division of the Reporting Person. The Reporting Person will then use these resources for similar programs or activities that advance the mission of the campus. This process is outlined in Section 105.4, specifically paragraphs 30 and 5e.  Additionally, the FAM states that an ancillary unit may be terminated if it remains on "inactive" status for 12 months or for other compelling reasons as determined by the Faculty Senate and Provost/Vice President of Academic Affairs (VPAA). The Faculty Senate and VPAA have the authority to initiate the termination process.
